intro: Rubus glandicaulis var. neoscoticus, commonly known as the Florida blackberry, is a perennial shrub native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its thorny stems and trifoliate leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that are typically dark purple to black when mature. It thrives in moist, acidic soils and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks. Its botanical features make it well adapted to humid, subtropical climates.
